name: Adult Contemporary
description: Slow to midtempo with a light and soothing tone, emerged as a successful radio format in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

name: Afrobeats
description: Originated in West Africa during the early 2010s and includes elements from Pop Rap, Contemporary R&B, and Dancehall.

children.name: Afropiano
children.description: Blends the easy-going, poppy, and melodic Afrobeats sound and rhythms with major Amapiano elements, like lush, jazzy, and laid-back atmospheres often featuring light piano chords.

children.name: Alté
children.description: More subdued, atmospheric, minimalist, and eclectic production and vocal styles compared to earlier styles, as well as more socially conscious lyrics.

name: Alt-Pop
description: Emerged in the late 2000s and early 2010s, combines chart Pop conventions with alternative/indie genre sensibilities sometimes on a more minimal and contemplative atmosphere, often extracted from Alternative R&B.

name: Arabic Pop
description: Synthesis of Arabic Music with Western Pop melodies, almost always sung in Arabic and typically performed with Arabic instruments, alongside some Western instruments like the guitar.

children.name: Al Jeel
children.description: Emerged in the 1970s as an alternative to Shaabi, taking influence from foreign Pop and incorporating rhythms of Reggae while retaining a distinctly Egyptian sound.

name: Art Pop
description: Artistic, inventive and singular presentation and performance, often featuring poetic or oblique lyricism, and frequently subverting and experimenting with various other genres and art forms while remaining fairly Pop-oriented and accessible.

name: Balkan Pop-Folk
description: Balkan popular music which blends Pop, Folk, and ethnic music.

children.name: Chalga
children.description: Bulgarian blend of Contemporary Folk (Turkish, Bulgarian, Arabic & Romani) with Dance-Pop.

children.name: Manele
children.description: Mixture of Romanian Music with Turkish, Middle Eastern, Balkan, and Romani influences, usually electronic in production.

children.name: Modern Laika
children.description: Laiki music mixed with popular Western music, most notably pop and dance.

children.name: Musika popullore
children.description: Tradition in Albania consisting of light, commercial, amplified Albanian Folk Music usually professionally arranged and manufactured in recording studios alongside video clips.

children.name: Muzică de mahala
children.description: Appeared in the 1980s, incorporating modern instruments and based on the model of Balkan Pop-Folk in neighboring countries.

children.name: Skiladika
children.description: Greek popular artists who used more Arabian elements; originally a derogatory term used to refer to a more decadent side of Laika.

children.name: Tallava
children.description: Mixture of Romani, Greek, Turkish, Albanian, and Slavic music, which incorporates Dance-Pop elements, and is very popular in Albania and Kosovo.

children.name: Turbo-Folk
children.description: Originated in Serbia during the 1980s, fusing traditional Western Balkan Folk Music with elements of contemporary popular music.

name: Baroque Pop
description: Incorporates elements of Western Classical Music, commonly featuring harpsichord or strings as well as the rhythmic flow and counterpoint of Baroque Music.

name: Bitpop
description: Fuses Bit Music with additional synths, beats, guitars and modern production values, emphasizing highly catchy melodies and relatively fast tempos.

name: Blue-Eyed Soul
description: Usually refers to a Pop or Pop Rock song that contains strong Gospel-like elements, primarily popularized by white American and British singers in the 1960s through the 1980s.

name: Boy Band
description: Male vocal groups often put together by talent managers or record producers.

name: Brega calypso
description: Romantic vocals and lyrics, bubbly and sensual melodies and rhythms, horn sections and lush Caribbean-like guitar riffs over fast tempos.

name: Brill Building
description: Elaborate, polished, and typically melodramatic composition and arrangement associated with the songwriting teams at the Brill office building during the late 1950s and early 1960s.

name: Bubblegum
description: Pop known for its upbeat, catchy simplicity and targeted at children and young teens; especially popular in the '60s and '70s.

name: Cambodian Pop
description: Popular music produced in Cambodia or by Khmer people.

children.name: Rom kbach
children.description: Cambodian pop with a slow melody that is similar to Luk thung.

name: Canción melódica
description: Sentimental vocal music sung in Spanish with a focus on the chorus, originally developed in the first half of the 20th century from a variety of traditional Hispanic genres.

children.name: Bolero-Beat
children.description: Latin American style stemming from both Canción melódica and the British Beat Music.

children.name: Música cebolla
children.description: Chilean offshoot of Canción melódica that expresses a much more melancholic or nostalgic side.

name: CCM
description: Popular music focused on Christian spirituality and faith.

children.name: Praise & Worship
children.description: Christian music with lyrics focused on the greatness of God.

name: City Pop
description: Wave of Japanese Pop intended to reflect urban life during the period of the country's booming economy in the 1970s and 1980s, featuring a contemporary Western sound and lush arrangements.

name: Classical Crossover
description: Takes specific Western Classical Music conventions and applies them into a straightfoward Pop context for mainstream appeal.

name: Country Pop
description: Combination of Country with Pop to appeal to a larger audience.

children.name: Bro-Country
children.description: Originated in the 21st century and takes its cues from Hip Hop, Pop and Contemporary Country.

children.name: Countrypolitan
children.description: Emphasizes Pop-oriented orchestration and songwriting while reducing the role of Country instrumentation and rhythms; often featuring lush string arrangements and group backing vocals.

children.name: Urban Cowboy
children.description: Melds country and Pop (best described as 70s L.A. soft pop), and sometimes leans towards Disco.

name: C-Pop
description: Commercialized pop performed by Chinese communities across China and Taiwan, alongside its large diaspora.

children.name: Cantopop
children.description: Cantonese-language Pop with its heyday in the 1980s and early 1990s.

children.name: Mandopop
children.description: C-Pop in which songs are performed in Mandarin.

children.name: Zhongguo feng
children.description: Inspired by traditional elements of Chinese Music with lyrical themes constantly revolving around Chinese culture and tales.

name: Dance-Pop
description: Simple, yet catchy melodies and throbbing beats inspired initially by Disco and later various House styles.

children.name: Bubblegum Dance
children.description: Playful, childlike style with a Bubblegum-like atmosphere that often incorporates high-pitched, light-hearted, and usually female-fronted vocals.

children.name: Disco polo
children.description: Polish Dance-Pop, originally established from contemporary wedding / feast songs and Italo-Disco.

children.name: Freestyle
children.description: Electro-influenced; developed in Latino communities in New York and Miami in the 1980s, especially dominated by Latin Freestyle and its Latin influences.

children.name: Latin Freestyle
children.description: Displays a heavy influence of Hispanic American Music alongside the Disco, Hip Hop, and Electro influences of Freestyle.

children.name: Funk melody
children.description: Derivative of Funk brasileiro in a Dance-Pop direction, originating in Rio de Janeiro.

children.name: Romanian Popcorn
children.description: Emerged in the second half of the 2000s in Romania, often featuring brass melodies and "staccato" pluck grooves.

children.name: Tecnorumba
children.description: Blend of the themes and singing style of Rumba flamenca with the most commercial forms of House, Techno, and Makina.

children.name: Township Bubblegum
children.description: Synth-heavy Dance-Pop style popular in the South African townships in the 1980s and early 1990s.

name: Dangdut
description: Indonesian popular music with Indian and Arabian influences which emerged in the early 1970s.

children.name: Dangdut koplo
children.description: Development of Javanese Dangdut which originated in Indonesia in the 1990s, featuring a faster tempo and influences from international styles like Pop, Rock, and Reggae.

name: Dansbandsmusik
description: Nordic form of Pop music growing out of the 1960s Pop Rock explosion, and incorporating influences from Swing, Schlager and sometimes Country into its repertoire.

name: Dansktop
description: Danish equivalent to Swedish Dansbandsmusik, German Volkstümliche Musik, and US Country; a coming together of folk and pop elements.

name: Denpa
description: Underground Japanese Pop aiming to be bizarre yet catchy, using off-key vocals, strange or nonsensical lyrics, repetitive chants, onomatopoeia, frantic, "off-kilter" production, and "moe" vocals and aesthetics.

name: Electropop
description: Dense, layered, and compressed production, usually coupled with a distinct fuzzy and "warm" low-frequency synthesizer style.

name: Europop
description: Emerged throughout mainland Europe in the early 1970s, referring to slick, highly commercial Pop songs that emphasize sugary melodies and light, bouncy instrumentation.

name: Flamenco Pop
description: Originally developed in the mid 1960s, incorporated palos flamencos (Flamenco subgenres) and Copla into the format of feisty and lively Pop (particularly, Yé-yé).

name: Folk Pop
description: Blends Contemporary Folk with a Pop sensibility, most popular in the late 1960s and early 1970s and featuring influence from the contemporary Folk Rock style.

children.name: Stomp and Holler
children.description: Highlights driving "stomping" rhythms and shouted group vocal harmonies, often drawing influences from Pop Rock, Indie Folk, and other genres, while maintaining a characteristically mellow and commercial sound.

name: French Pop
description: Pop originating from France.

name: Girl Group
description: Combines elements of Rhythm & Blues, Rock & Roll, and Traditional Pop; typically performed by trios or quartets of female vocalists.

name: Glitch Pop
description: Incorporates elements of more experimental Electronic styles like IDM and Glitch.

name: Hyperpop
description: Developed and took inspiration from Bubblegum Bass and popular 2000s-2010s Electropop, characterized by eclectic, unconventional, mechanical-sounding and dense production; and by manipulated, usually auto-tuned vocals.

name: Indian Pop
description: Commonly based out of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh and almost always sung in Hindi, Urdu or Bengali, implements South Asian Music in context of American and European Pop and Rock music.

name: Indie Pop
description: Back-to-basics Rock approach combining a less mainstream and DIY ethos with melodic, lighthearted and straightforward songwriting.

children.name: Bedroom Pop
children.description: Named for solo producers and singer-songwriters from the 2010s onward who created intimate, "authentic" music in their own homes, outside of a traditional studio environment.

children.name: C86
children.description: Distinctly ramshackle, often Twee Pop-infused combination of British Indie Rock and Jangle Pop.

children.name: Chamber Pop
children.description: Based on the smooth and melodic songwriting of Lounge and other Easy Listening, as well as the orchestration of Baroque Pop and the production styles of other 1960s pop genres.

children.name: Neo-Acoustic
children.description: Japanese term for a cross-section of Indie Pop and Jangle Pop with more prominent acoustic instrumentation and songwriting/arrangements that draw from Sophisti-Pop.

children.name: Sonido Donosti
children.description: Sentimental and melancholic scene, influenced by Twee Pop, that emerged in the late 1980s in Donostia / San Sebastián, Spain.

children.name: Tontipop
children.description: Spanish scene known for its exuberant, child-like sound drawing directly from British Twee Pop, as well as Yé-yé, Bubblegum, and Synthpop.

children.name: Twee Pop
children.description: Distinct Post-Punk background and often jangling guitars, defined by a cute aesthetic and lyrics combined with an indie/DIY attitude and a simplicity often indebted to Punk Rock.

name: Irish Showband
description: Phenomenon lasting from the mid-1950s until the early 1980s, often performed a mixture of currently popular music and skits.

name: Italo Pop
description: Romantic style developed in Italy in the late 1950s including various influences such as Chanson and Schlager.

children.name: Canzone neomelodica
children.description: Elements are derived from Canzone napoletana.

name: Jazz Pop
description: Pop that incorporates elements from Jazz.

name: J-Pop
description: Commercial Pop of Japan after the advent of the Heisei era (1989), characterized by modernized production, a more eclectic sound palette, and a more westernized vocal style.

children.name: Akishibu-kei
children.description: Otaku inclined update of the style pioneered by the Shibuya-kei scene, mixed with J-Pop and often tied to Anime and video game music.

children.name: Yakousei
children.description: Eclectic scene from Japan popularized in the late 2010s; characterized by Dance-influenced rhythms, Indie Pop and Indie Rock's approaches to composition and a focus on vocal delivery and introspective lyricism.

name: Kayōkyoku
description: Japanese popular music prominent during the later period of the Shōwa era (early 1950s to late 1980s).

children.name: Idol kayō
children.description: More Westernized and upbeat form of Kayōkyoku popular in the 1970s and 1980s which acted as a precursor to J-Pop.

children.name: Mood kayō
children.description: Early form of Kayōkyoku dominant in the 1950s and 1960s, prominently influenced by American Jazz, Hispanic American Music, and Hawaiian Music.

children.name: Techno kayō
children.description: Offshoot of 1980s Kayōkyoku and Idol kayō incorporating characteristics from Synthpop.

name: Korean Ballad
description: South Korean Pop from the 1980s to the early 90s taking influence from western Blues, Synthpop, Soul and Contemporary Folk.

children.name: Oriental Ballad
children.description: Emerged in the late 1990s in South Korea, taking influence from more traditional forms of Korean Music.

name: K-Pop
description: Contemporary Pop scene in South Korea based on multiple mainstream influences such as Contemporary R&B, Dance-Pop, and Hip Hop.

children.name: Semi-Trot
children.description: Contemporary form of Trot which takes influences from modern K-Pop and recent Pop substyles.

name: Latin Pop
description: Characterized by its usage of Latino clichés and frequently influenced by traditional Latin American styles, commonly borrowing from their instrumentation.

children.name: Cumbia pop
children.description: Developed in the Río de la Plata region in the mid-2010s, featuring Latin Pop influences and lyrics related to romance, youth, and fun.

children.name: Tropipop
children.description: Subgenre of Colombian origin fusing Vallenato instrumentation into a Latin Pop context.

name: Lokal musik
description: Created by local, rural artists from Papua New Guinea that incorporate some elements of Papuan Folk Music into Pop.

name: Mulatós
description: Upbeat, danceable Hungarian Pop that takes strong influence from Hungarian Folk Music and Romani Folk Music.

name: Nederpop
description: Dutch language Pop which originally arose in the 1970s to describe the style of the 1950s and 1960s, but would also later be used for 1980s artists who incorporated elements of Ska and Reggae.

children.name: Palingsound
children.description: Originating from Volendam in the Netherlands; harmonizing vocals and orchestrated arrangements.

name: New Music
description: Developed when Japanese Singer-Songwriters incorporated elements of Contemporary Folk and Pop Rock with Kayōkyoku songwriting.

name: New Romantic
description: UK pop cultural movement associated with the early 1980s and defined by a distinct, flamboyant fashion sense.

name: OPM
description: Style of pop balladry originating from the Philippines as a successor of the Manila Sound.

name: Orthodox Pop
description: Combines Orthodox Jewish themes and prayer with Pop songwriting, usually sung in Hebrew.

name: Persian Pop
description: Hybrid of Iranian and Persian-language popular music with Western instruments such as the guitar, drum kit, and synthesizer.

name: Pop Batak
description: Combines Western genres of music and instrumentation with a typical Batak flair, like lyrics about Batak life and the use of some traditional Batak instruments.

name: Pop Ghazal
description: Employs traditional Ghazal's verse, meter, and poetic inclinations in a pop form.

name: Pop Minang
description: Combines Minangkabau traditions with Pop structures and instrumentation.

children.name: Talempong goyang
children.description: Blends traditional Talempong elements with contemporary Pop influences, often featuring a female vocalist, and encourages audience participation.

name: Pop Raï
description: Fuses melodic sensibilities into the traditional Raï structure, with increased utilization of synthesizers, guitars, and drum machines.

name: Pop Reggae
description: Light, commercial form of Reggae designed to crossover and break through to a more mainstream Pop audience.

name: Pop Rock
description: Standard verse-chorus Pop that can also be categorized under Rock for its use of guitars, drums, and propulsive rhythms.

children.name: Beat Music
children.description: Emerged in the early 1960s in the United Kingdom, drawing on Rock & Roll and the late 1950s Skiffle revival.

children.name: Freakbeat
children.description: Combined elements of British Rhythm & Blues, Beat Music, and Pop Rock with the studio effects of Psychedelia - fuzztones, flanging, chorus - to create a style often seen as a British relative of American Garage Rock and Psychedelic Rock.

children.name: Group Sounds
children.description: Japanese bands in the mid-to-late 1960s who began performing a style of Beat Music primarily in English.

children.name: Jovem Guarda
children.description: 1960s Brazilian youth-oriented Pop Rock, with romantic lyrics and influenced by Merseybeat and Rockabilly.

children.name: Merseybeat
children.description: Light, highly melodic style of Beat Music popular in the UK during the early 1960s, named due to the abundance of bands from Liverpool beside the River Mersey.

children.name: Nederbeat
children.description: Dutch answer to the UK Beat Music boom of the 1960s.

children.name: Big Music
children.description: Rooted in Post-Punk and popular in the 1980s, with anthemic songwriting and a grandiose, stadium-ready sound.

children.name: Britpop
children.description: Emerged in the United Kingdom in the early 1990s, with a style hearkening back to the traditional guitar-driven songs and melodic hooks found in the British Pop Rock of the 1960s.

children.name: Jangle Pop
children.description: Pop-oriented songwriting based around chiming jangly guitar lines, and propulsive rhythms often drawn from Post-Punk.

children.name: C86
children.description: Distinctly ramshackle, often Twee Pop-infused combination of British Indie Rock and Jangle Pop.

children.name: Neo-Acoustic
children.description: Japanese term for a cross-section of Indie Pop and Jangle Pop with more prominent acoustic instrumentation and songwriting/arrangements that draw from Sophisti-Pop.

children.name: Paisley Underground
children.description: Emerged in Los Angeles in the early 1980s, featuring the energy of Power Pop and New Wave adorned with retro Psychedelia.

children.name: Manila Sound
children.description: Philippine Pop Rock movement most prominent in the 1970s; served as a predecessor of OPM.

children.name: Piano Rock
children.description: Based around the piano, as opposed to most traditional Rock, which is based around the guitar.

children.name: Post-Britpop
children.description: Emerged in the late 1990s as a Britpop expansion mainly characterized by acoustic-leaning instrumentation, lush string arrangements, and mid-tempo song structures, as well as less apparent lyrical concerns for Britain in favor of introspective, contemplative themes.

children.name: Power Pop
children.description: Heavier Pop Rock that combines strong Pop melodies with loud power chords, characterized by prominent electric guitars, clear vocals, crisp harmonies, and economical arrangements.

children.name: Soft Rock
children.description: Light, melodic, radio-friendly Rock which gained huge commercial success in the 1970s.

children.name: Tropical Rock
children.description: Combines influences from Country Rock and Caribbean Music to create an acoustic and breezy "island" themed sound.

children.name: Yacht Rock
children.description: Slick Pop Rock influenced by smoother R&B styles, popular in the late 1970s and often associated with California.

children.name: Sonido Donosti
children.description: Sentimental and melancholic scene, influenced by Twee Pop, that emerged in the late 1980s in Donostia / San Sebastián, Spain.

children.name: Stereo
children.description: Burmese Pop Rock genre which emerged in the mid-1960s.

children.name: Twee Pop
children.description: Distinct Post-Punk background and often jangling guitars, defined by a cute aesthetic and lyrics combined with an indie/DIY attitude and a simplicity often indebted to Punk Rock.

children.name: Vocal Surf
children.description: Appropriates the sounds of instrumental Surf Rock, combining surfing- and car-themed lyrics with a style that draws primarily from Doo-Wop and Rock & Roll.

name: Pop Soul
description: Fusion of Pop and Soul; originated in the 1960s as an attempt to give soul crossover success.

children.name: Motown Sound
children.description: Succinct, catchy song structures; complex arrangements; Gospel-influenced vocals; highly melodic and rhythmic bass lines; 4-4 drum patterns; often syncopated piano parts; regular use of horn and string sections; and historically a distinctive reverb and treble-heavy production.

name: Pop Sunda
description: Mixes Sundanese traditions with Pop structures and instrumentation.

name: Progressive Pop
description: Milder counterpart to Progressive Rock, emerging in the late 1960s and introducing complex songwriting and arrangements into a Pop context.

name: Psychedelic Pop
description: Combines unconventional instrumentation with studio effects to create a psychedelic atmosphere within melodic Pop music.

name: Rabiz
description: Elements of Armenian folk in its instrumentation, oftentimes incorporating influences from Arabic and other West Asian forms on a background of synthesizer arrangements.

name: Rigsar
description: Dominant form of popular music in Bhutan which broke traditions to move towards a more Western and Indian approach.

name: Rumba catalana
description: Cheerful Catalan genre that takes influences from Rumba cubana, Andalusian Rumba flamenca, and Pop.

name: Russian Chanson
description: Divided into lyrical and criminal chanson, it is best described as narrative-driven popular music inspired by crime and prison.

name: Schlager
description: Light, sentimental, melodic pop music common mainly in northern and central Europe.

children.name: Humppa
children.description: Finnish music related to Jazz and the foxtrot.

children.name: Levenslied
children.description: Dutch genre that enjoyed widespread popularity in the pre-Rock & Roll era. with simple melody and rhythm and lyrics composed of couplets and refrains.

children.name: Volkstümliche Musik
children.description: Light Pop with borrowings from German Folk Music (volksmusik), often misleadingly labeled as being volksmusik.

name: Sertanejo romântico
description: Hybrid of Brazilian Sertanejo with Pop production and aesthetics, made popular nationwide during the mid-to-late 1980s.

name: Sertanejo universitário
description: Third evolution of Sertanejo, sharing close sensibilities with national Brazilian Pop music and other regional styles.

children.name: Arrocha sertanejo
children.description: Merged the Arrocha style with the younger audience creating a more energetic and more danceable rhythm.

children.name: Funknejo
children.description: Incorporates the rhythms, production, and idioms of Funk brasileiro into the universitário genre.

name: Sophisti-Pop
description: Incorporates influences from Jazz, classic R&B and Soul along with a slick, polished production style while retaining elements from its New Wave roots.

name: Soviet Estrada
description: Emerged in the USSR during the early 1930s, and encompassed the dominating popular music style composed by government-approved songwriters and the primary repertoire of professionally trained performers.

name: Sunshine Pop
description: Retrospective term for a more cheerful or wistful style of Pop which emerged in the mid-1960s as "soft pop".

name: Synthpop
description: Led by a prominent, melodic synthesizer sound, often with reverberated drum machine patterns that create a distinct atmospheric feel commonly associated with the 1980s.

children.name: Futurepop
children.description: Derivative of EBM, retaining its apocalyptic worldview but incorporating heavy influence from the melodic style of Synthpop.

children.name: Pon-chak disco
children.description: Heavily influenced by Electro-Disco, featuring cheap "electronic organ" synth leads and minimalistic, repetitive rhythms.

children.name: Techno kayō
children.description: Offshoot of 1980s Kayōkyoku and Idol kayō incorporating characteristics from Synthpop.

name: Teen Pop
description: Oriented to teen audiences and almost always sung by teens.

name: Traditional Pop
description: Predominant form of Western commercial popular music in the pre-Rock & Roll era, particularly in the USA and starting with Tin Pan Alley; typically vocal-oriented with an orchestral arrangement.

children.name: British Dance Band
children.description: Came from the dancehalls of the 1920s and 1930s, combining a British take on Jazz with the Music Hall tradition.

children.name: Mood kayō
children.description: Early form of Kayōkyoku dominant in the 1950s and 1960s, prominently influenced by American Jazz, Hispanic American Music, and Hawaiian Music.

children.name: Romanţe
children.description: Expressive and poetic Romanian style, generally sung similar to a Chanson and composed for piano and guitar orchestral arrangements.

children.name: Standards
children.description: Traditional compositions originating from the 1910s and onward which have become widely known, performed, and recorded across the world.

children.name: Tin Pan Alley
children.description: Early era of popular song in the USA, broadly from the 1890s-1930s; influences include Ragtime, Vaudeville and parlour music.

name: Turkish Pop
description: Started in the late 1950s, when Turkish artists started to write their own lyrics to Western popular tunes.

name: Vocal Trance
description: Melodic, polished, Pop-like, and vocal-focused with around 120-145 BPM and frequent overlap with Progressive Trance, Uplifting Trance, and Euro-Trance.

name: V-Pop
description: Western-sounding pop with Vietnamese lyrics, or pop that borrows sounds from popular Vietnamese genres and re-imagines them with more accessible and/or upbeat structures.

name: Yé-yé
description: Upbeat, trendy Pop that emerged in Southern Europe in the early 1960s, focusing on image and risqué lyrics.
